snippet: If it hasn’t happened already, it will: at some point, even by accident, your child will click on pornography.

headline.main: So How Do We Talk About This?
headline.print_headline: So How Do We Talk About This?

snippet: The windfall from Facebook’s public offering may prompt some employees to leave, in what could be one of company’s lasting legacies — a new generation of tech tycoons looking to create or invest in, well, the next Facebook.
abstract: Windfall from Facebook’s public offering may prompt some employees to leave, in what could be one of company’s lasting legacies--a new generation of tech tycoons looking to create or invest in their own companies, or bankroll their friends; while every public offering creates a new circle of tech magnates with money to invest, Facebook's, with a jaw-dropping $100 billion valuation, will create a far richer fraternity.

headline.main: A Circle of Tech: Collect Payout, Do a Start-Up
headline.print_headline: A Circle of Tech: Collect Payout, Do a Start-Up

snippet: Ciudad Juárez is still a violent city, but homicide rates have decreased significantly from their peak in 2010, and young people in particular are stepping out.
abstract: Ciudad Juarez Journal; signs of new life appear in the violent border city of Ciudad Juarez, Mex, as homicide rates decrease and young people in particular are stepping out, hosting fashion shows, joining art collectives and partying after dark at reopened nightclubs.

headline.main: Slivers of Hope Amid the Melancholy in a Mexican Border Town
headline.print_headline: Slivers of Hope Amid the Melancholy in a Mexican Border Town

snippet: The VoiceLive Play is like a guitar stomp box, but for singers. It even supplies backup vocalists.
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column highlights the VoiceLive Play gadget ($250 online) from vocal-processing company TC Helicon; notes it has foot-controlled buttons to control effects like reverb and autotune; points out a singer can perform with accompaniment or alone, and the processor can provide the backup vocals.

snippet: Pelican, which makes protective cases often used by the military, now sells a case designed for people who fear their iPads are in for some serious abuse.
abstract: Pelican, which makes protective cases often used by the military, now sells a case designed for people who fear their iPads are in for some serious abuse.

headline.main: A Bombproof Case for Your iPad
headline.print_headline: A Hard Case for Protecting Electronics From Life’s Knocks

snippet: A new release of Apple's operating system for mobile devices and tablets, iOS 5.1.1, addresses some bugs found in the previous version.
abstract: A new release of Apple's operating system for mobile devices and tablets, iOS 5.1.1, addresses some bugs found in the previous version.

snippet: Aston Martin is sending off its DBS coupe and convertible with a limited-edition build, appropriately called the Ultimate.
abstract: Aston Martin is sending off its DBS coupe and convertible with a limited-edition build, appropriately called the Ultimate.

snippet: You probably aren't expecting your iPad to be hit by an improvised explosive device, but if you are, you might want to secure it in a Pelican case.     Pelican, which makes protective cases often used by the military to transport weapons, medical ...
abstract: Gadgetwise blog highlights Pelican's i1075 Hardback iPad protective case. Photo (M)1

headline.main: A Hard Case for Protecting Electronics From Life's Knocks

snippet: Silicon Valley doesn't have much love for Wall Street, perceiving buttoned-up financiers as fee-obsessed number crunchers who don't really understand technology.     But Michael Grimes of Morgan Stanley, a gadget enthusiast with a computer science...
abstract: Michael Grimes, Morgan Stanley managing director of global technology, has helped lead 28 technology initial pubic offerings over the past year, including those for LinkedIn and Zynga; he is preparing for his biggest debut yet: Facebook, which could raise more than $10 billion in May; Morgan Stanley could collect more than $35 million for its work on Facebook, depending on the size of the offering. Graph, Photos (M)

snippet: In most cases, ''Mad Men'' is bound by the history of the era in which it takes place. But on Sunday night, a new episode of that 1960s period drama that concluded with the Beatles song ''Tomorrow Never Knows'' appears to have made some history of...
abstract: Beatles song Tomorrow Never Knows is featured in an episode of the series Mad Men, one of only a handful of times that a Beatles track has been licensed to a television show in the United States. Photo (M)1

headline.main: A '60s Show Finally Gets to Play a Song by the Quintessential '60s Group

byline.original: By DAVE ITZKOFF and BEN SISARIO
